tit.cmt: タイトルなので大文字にしました。

sen.j: 浄土真宗遣迎院派（じょうどしんしゅうけんごういんは）は浄土真宗の一派。
sen.e: Kengoin school of Jodo Shinshu sect is one of the schools of Jodo Shinshu.

sen.j: 昭和30年（1955年）、天台宗の寺院であった遣迎院が独立して一派を興した。

sen.j: 浄土真宗と標榜しているものの、本尊に釈迦如来、阿弥陀如来の二尊を立てるなど、他の真宗教団とは教義的にも関連が薄い。
sen.e: Although they aim at Jodo Shinshu sect, they have no strong relations with other religious communities of Jodo Shinshu sects also in terms of religious principle as they adopted two honzon (principal image of Buddha) of Shaka Nyorai (Shakyamuni) and Amida Nyorai (Amitabha Tathagata.)
sen.cmt: 「浄土真宗と標榜している」を「浄土真宗を標榜している」と読み替えて訳しました。
sen.e: Although it aims for the Jodo Shinshu sect, it doesn't have strong relations with other religious communities of Jodo Shinshu sects in terms of religious principles, as it has adopted the two honzon (principal image of Buddha) of Shaka Nyorai (Shakyamuni) and Amida Nyorai (Amitabha Tathagata).

Although it aims for the Jodo Shinshu sect, it doesn't have strong relations with other religious communities of Jodo Shinshu sects in terms of religious principles, as it has adopted the two honzon (principal image of Buddha) of Shaka Nyorai (Shakyamuni) and Amida Nyorai (Amitabha Tathagata).

sen.j: なお、遣迎院の院号は、浄土へ「遣」わす釈迦、浄土で「迎」える阿弥陀に由来する。
sen.e: Ingo (a title of temple), "Kengoin" is derived from two Chinese characters "遣 (to send)" and "迎 (to receive)" that mean Shaka sends people to Jodo (Pure Land of Amida Buddha) and Amida welcomes people at the Pure Land.
